awd_titl_txt: RAISE: Neighborhood Environments as Socio-Techno-bio Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This inter-disciplinary RAISE award is jointly funded by the Cultural Anthropology Program, the Environmental Engineering Program, the Biological Anthropology Program, the Science, Technology, and Society Program, the Office of Integrative Activities, the Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences Directorate, and the Engineering Directorate. The overarching goal is to develop methodological tools for understanding complex, dynamic socio-techno-biological systems connected through feedback loops between socio-economic conditions, environments, and human biological trajectories. This will be done by engaging a team of environmental engineers, anthropologists, and epidemiologists in a multi-faceted case study of water trust. The researchers have chosen water trust as a focus for developing these integrative methodologies because environmental engineers have found that the deterioration of trust in water can be as important as water quality in determining whether people access safe water. However, understanding why this is so requires combining environmental, anthropological, and health research. This will model an approach amenable to use in other locations and with other systems, which will contribute to a more general understanding of linked complex systems across engineering and the social and life sciences.  

The researchers will collect data on linkages between water trust, real-time water quality, neighborhood environments, inequality, and health. The research will be carried out in fifteen neighborhoods in Mexico City, which is an appropriate site for the research because neighborhoods there have distinct identities and the researchers have access to longitudinal data on residents' health trajectories. Also, because it has many water challenges, Mexico City is a good testbed for probing technical, social, and biological interactions and feedbacks at a neighborhood-systems level. The researchers will collect data In a sample of households in 15 neighborhoods. Data will include: qualitative ethnographic data (water use, trust in water quality, water provisioning structures, social cohesion, security, food environments, and built environments); quantitative socio-economic data using a neighborhood assessment scale; environmental engineering data, including, grab sampling to measure water quality characteristics (such as toxicants, viruses, trace organics, and antibiotic resistance genes) that are linked to biological alterations in humans; and real-time high-resolution sensor measurements of basic water quality parameters (temperature, pressure, turbidity, and chlorine residue). They will also collect urine samples from all household residents to monitor movement of contaminants through residents' bodies; engage residents as citizen scientists through text messaging about water quality, system breakdowns, and availability; and leverage existing longitudinal molecular epidemiological data previously collected on mother child/pairs in these neighborhoods. These data will be compiled to model the interlinked and feedback relationships between human behaviors, built environments, and biological processes in the creation of water trust.

por.por_cntn:
The NESTSMX project, which combines anthropology, engineering, epidemiology and environmental health, has had several impactful outcomes. The most significant outcome is that the team members were invited to use NESTSMX data about the conditions and dynamics of intermittent water supply (IWS) to develop a survey module for the ENSANUT (Encuesta Nacional de Salud y Nutrición) - México's nationally representative health and nutrition survey, in order to better understand the relationship between IWS and health, gender, and economics. Our team used NESTSMX data to develop survey measures about themes that emerged as important throughout the NESTSMX household visits. These included the frequency of water supply, household water storage and treatment practices, and the source of water for drinking, cooking, and cleaning. The survey module was deployed for the first time in 2022, and our team made several important findings with the resulting data that have been published in México's leading public health journal, Salud Pública de México. Our research shows that even though the previous Mexican census estimated that 96% of Mexican households have piped water, only 17% of households experienced a continuous water supply year round. Intermittency compels household members to store water, and in fact we found that in 2022, 80% of Mexican households reported storing water. Our findings have garnered national attention in México, receiving front page media coverage in Reforma, a national newspaper.  

NESTSMX data have also directly led to important and innovative findings. In a paper published in PLOS Water, team members integrated NESTSMX ethnographic data with an independent household survey and found that residents invested time, labor, and resources to make intermittent water supply enough for their daily needs. These investments are costly, both monetarily and because intensive water management compromises residents' ability to trust in their water for drinking. We have also found, that water storage can decrease water quality through mechanisms such as chlorine degradation, so even when publicly supplied water arrives to households meeting water quality standards, storage often makes it unfit to drink. Together, these findings about the relationship between water intermittency, water storage, and water quality lead to important new lines of inquiry. Deteriorating water quality makes it so household members must then leave the house to purchase drinking water, which makes them more likely to purchase soda, which is cheap, delicious, and easier to carry than the large water jugs (garrafones) that are often sold for drinking water use. Thus, while the public health literature links intermittent water supply (IWS) to infectious diseases through this water quality deterioration, our findings indicate that IWS is likely to impact chronic diseases, like diabetes and obesity, by creating the conditions for household members to drink soda instead of water. NESTSMX team members will continue to explore these hypotheses using ENSANUT data. 

The other significant impact of NESTSMX is methodological. Our team has demonstrated that complex problems like water trust can be better understood through the interactive, multidisciplinary processes made possible by the NSF RAISE funding mechanism. We have published reflections about our interdisciplinary work in American Anthropologist and Catalyst and are in the process of writing a paper describing our methodology in detail to inform other teams who seek to integrate diverse methods for studying complex socio-techno-environmental problems, such as water trust. The water quality sensors NESTSMX deployed were also methodologically innovative, an approach which we have documented in a publication in ACS ES&T Engineering. NESTSMX data has also led to the development of innovative analysis that leverages ethnographic data to create quantitative variables about water supply and household experiences of water quality, then uses factor analysis to synthesize ethnographically-derived variables with other quantitative indicators of water infrastructure, quality, and management. These innovative synthesized variables integrated data gathered through methods from engineering, anthropology, and surveys to test hypothesized pathways linking intermittent water supply to household storage, household water quality, and residents' experiences of their water quality. 

The extensive data collected through NESTSMX research have been stored in a secure data system. Our datasets are available to external researchers upon request and application, offering a rich source for researchers to create ethnographically derived hypotheses, test quantitative questions, or bring these methods together in innovative ways. 

Finally, the team is currently developing a proposal for an intervention trial to test if water filters might mitigate the impact of water intermittency on beverage consumption. In this way, using small 'n' ethnography to inform statistically powerful data collection tools has led to new lines of inquiry, novel hypotheses, and training in innovative mixed methods approaches, which has been the aim of the NESTSMX project since its inception.
